prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus binaries (central, wide)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Binaries in the central part of Taurus that require only comparatively low (> 1 arcsecond) resolution to resolve the 3 mm continuum emission among the components.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sources listed in this science goal are those in the central part of Taurus that have separations greater than about 1 arcsecond, but less than the largest angular scale ALMA is sensitive to at Band 3, ~ 25 arcseconds. These systems therefore require comparatively low-resolution (1 arcsecond) data for photometric measurements of the individual stellar components' disks.
The correlator has been set up to provide maximal continuum sensitivity: 4 spectral windows have been assigned for dual polarization observations, with a total (single polarization) bandwidth 2 GHz each.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus binaries (east)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Eastern Taurus binaries (each of these only requires 1 arcsecond resolution)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sources listed in this science goal are those in the eastern part of Taurus that have separations greater than about 1 arcsecond, but less than the largest angular scale ALMA is sensitive to at Band 3, ~ 25 arcseconds. These systems therefore require comparatively low-resolution (1 arcsecond) data for photometric measurements of the individual stellar components' disks.
The correlator has been set up to provide maximal continuum sensitivity: 4 spectral windows have been assigned for dual polarization observations, with a total (single polarization) bandwidth 2 GHz each.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus binaries (south)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Binaries in the southern part of Taurus. Each of these only requires low resolution (> 1 arcsecond) resolution observations

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sources listed in this science goal are those in the southern part of Taurus that have separations greater than about 1 arcsecond, but less than the largest angular scale ALMA is sensitive to at Band 3, ~ 25 arcseconds. These systems therefore require comparatively low-resolution (1 arcsecond) data for photometric measurements of the individual stellar components' disks.
The correlator has been set up to provide maximal continuum sensitivity: 4 spectral windows have been assigned for dual polarization observations, with a total (single polarization) bandwidth 2 GHz each.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus binaries (central, close )
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Binaries in the central part of Taurus that require high-angular resolution (< 1 arcsecond; typically < 0.5 arcseconds) to resolve the continuum emission between components.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sources listed in this science goal are those in the central part of Taurus that have separations less than about 1 arcsecond because the largest angular scale that ALMA is sensitive to in its most extended configuration at Band 3 is ~ 8 arcseconds, we do not require additional configurations (no system has any component more widely separated than a few arcseconds). These systems typically require 0.5, and, for a few systems, sub 0.5 arcsecond, resolution data for photometric measurements of the individual stellar components' disks.
The correlator has been set up to provide maximal continuum sensitivity: 4 spectral windows have been assigned for dual polarization observations, with a total (single polarization) bandwidth 2 GHz each.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The growth of grains from sub-micron to centimeter sizes comprise the first steps of core accretion, the dominant paradigm for planet formation. It has been suggested that the presence of a stellar companion should negatively impact this process through enhanced stirring of disk material by the periodic perturbation of the companion. Whether or not this is in fact the case is very important to understanding the first steps of planet formation in multiple star systems -- the dominant outcome of Galactic star formation. Checking this hypothesis requires multi-band (sub)millimeter photometry to assess the spectral index of the disk dust emission and -- by proxy -- the extent of grain growth in disks in multiple systems. In this proposal, we propose a sensitive, component-resolved survey of the Band 3 (100 GHz) continuum emission from circumstellar/system disks in a set of Taurus multiples. The results of this survey -- when combined with those of previous component-resolved surveys -- will allow, for the first time, an assessment of the extent to which multiplicity affects the first steps of planet formation in multiple systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, University of
